content.title: Recurrent Carotid Stenosis
content.description: Stenosis developing after prior carotid endarterectomy or stenting, with distinct pathophysiology and management considerations compared to primary disease.
content.definition: Recurrent carotid stenosis is narrowing at a previously treated carotid site. Early recurrence (<2 years) is typically due to myointimal hyperplasia (smooth, low embolization risk), while late recurrence (>2 years) represents new atherosclerosis (higher stroke risk). Management depends on symptom status and timing of recurrence.

pathophysiology_by_timing: Early lesions: Smooth, less prone to embolization
Late lesions: Ulcerated, higher stroke risk
incidence: Higher after primary closure vs patch closure
Higher after eversion CEA in some studies
evaluation: CTA/MRA for surgical planning if significant
Assess for symptoms - asymptomatic may be observed
management: CAS often preferred for post-CEA recurrence
Redo CEA technically challenging (scar, cranial nerves)
Patch angioplasty if redo CEA performed

learning_objectives: Distinguish early vs late recurrent stenosis
clinical_pearls: Early recurrence (myointimal hyperplasia) often benign - low stroke risk
Late recurrence (atherosclerosis) behaves like primary disease
CAS preferred for redo to avoid cranial nerve injury from scarring
Patch closure reduces recurrence compared to primary closure
Lifetime surveillance is required after CEA
